text: 2,000 miles from war-torn Afghanistan
historian Jin Zhu examines a series of
unusual beehive structures built in
northern China one and a half centuries
before the minaret of jam this imposing
and the towering structure is the
remains of a huge lost kingdom the
gigantic mounts formed the royal burial
site of the tangled empire a lost
medieval civilization whose population
was once vast we know precious little
about their real social structure
because all they've left behind us his
ruins this dead Kingdom fell victim to a
ferocious warlord whose name became
synonymous with terror across Asia and
Europe
Genghis Khan in order to conquer China
the Mongols had first to conquer penguin
Kingdom in the early 13th century
Genghis Khan's army invaded tangled
territory the Tangut emperor chose to
surrender rather than fight he came to
Genghis his tent with tokens of all the
wealth of his kingdom seven great horses
seven great virgins seven great chests
of treasure to offer his surrender
the Tangut emperor waits for three days
in front of content he doesn't know that
the Great Khan is mortally ill Khan's
last words to his sons are chilling as
Genghis was lying on his deathbed he
instructed his sons let everyone in this
kingdom vanish the sad thing is that the
Mongols took him to his world the first
to be killed is the tankard Emperor
himself executed in front of Genghis
Khan's deathbed then the mass killing
begins genghis is success organized
destroyed all their cities literally
reduce their society to ruins killing
millions people in the process is one of
the most the tragic chapters in human
history in which a great civilization
has disappeared
the destruction of the Tangut empire
sets the stage for Agha daikons bloody
campaign of conquest so why were the
Beehive structures the only thing
remaining it's testament it's
intentionally left in order to preserve
the memory that this is what will happen
if you deny the Mongol Kingdom
